I'm now reaching a point where I need a solution to share logfiles from devices with colleagues in a convenient way, one that allows stream live logs, but also organise sessions using tagging, naming. Does that exist? https://t.co/MSrnUlhU7V
@leastpossible Hm, looks interesting, seems a little too much focused on support cases. I'd prefer something more lightweight.
@johnjonesname @RealIvanSanchez What do you use as destination that allows to easily and secretly share a log session?
@RealIvanSanchez @johnjonesname I did not say that.
Johnny 5 is alive! https://t.co/Qy6lnv2dhh

@raae https://t.co/5pnoBXwpiP

... or if you love YAML: https://t.co/Dyrb9Xrvh4
@johnjonesname Interesting, thanks!
@5422m4n But how do you share a log session?
@5422m4n I have multiple devices / firmware version / bugs that I am debugging, so for a specific combination of those I want to be able to collect and share the logs.

@AndyScherzinger It's 5 years old, and I have no experience with the newer ones. However reviews were generally very good, and OLED looks great: https://t.co/TMxgYpeSfp

So I'd pick that with 32 GB RAM and i7. https://t.co/E9g7gxM7Nr
@serapath Does that work for continuously appended streams as well?
It's amazing how much shit can be put in one single tweet. https://t.co/vnYnG3G8RD

@ulfkar Those are @NordicTweets Thingy:91s: https://t.co/oRpnCmfyW6 and they run one of the applications from our SDK: https://t.co/2Ik0lcpwFr

61 developers are now millionaires because StackOverflow was sold, and people will use this as a great example to push the "equity instead of cash" agenda.

Consider for a second how many developers you know *personally* that got this lucky.

And if you consider taking equity instead of cash consider if everyone in your company has the privilege of being able to exchange money today for a slim bet on future income that very often can be voided unilaterally.

Hei friends! I am attending @SoCraTes_UK and I miss having breakfast with other people who share my passion about software... #SoCraTesUK https://t.co/rh5y7hJUdM
@Maaikees Don't they have these regular doors at the side of them, which nobody notices?
@terabaud Herrje.
@Maaikees https://t.co/IHRxCLS9sA
We have a full schedule ahead! #SoCraTesUK https://t.co/2DuAYXMPY8

First session: #OKRs - Share Your Learnings at #SoCraTesUK.
Looking forward to discuss since I feel this is a often misused tool and it's great to hear about other experiences with them.

If you are not aware of them: https://t.co/Ok3J648nEb

In my experience the problem is not the definition itself, but finding good OKRs.
I also see them as a good framework to discuss one's purpose in the organization and what you are contributing, even if you leave out the measurement part.
But it's important to realize that some (even critical) functions in an organization cannot be measured.
Interesting book recommendation from @branaby: https://t.co/99v57F3W1G

It seems like we exclusively have issues with measuring results. And the literature makes this look way too easy. As a profession we could research more and get a better understanding of if that part of OKRs is more harmful.
@branaby Bought ... looking forward to this.
Session notes: https://t.co/KzQOsOcu2v

Second #SoCraTesUK session was one I held (so not much summary here, sorry): Better way for documenting Architecture visually (what about the glue?).

Notes: https://t.co/gpDkPsBpYF

Now in the #SoCraTesUK session with the world's best kata facilitator @malk_zameth, and practicing my architecture diagramming skills on the FizzBuzz kata. I tried two variants. https://t.co/qP6mGlmb8k
Changed the style a little with the Roman Numerals kata: https://t.co/tCJ8dJHIms

Now doing some session hopping at #SoCraTesUK, first looking into how to TDD "simple" problems, now in @ezagroba session career options for experts.
Both are fascinating, open exchanges.
Now in the #SoCraTesUK session about trunk vs feature branch development.
First, going over the basics: https://t.co/oa0Vd17gny explains it very well.
It seems like everyone in the session is onboard with trunk-based-development already.
Confidence for TBD can also come from good monitoring.
@Lazer Wasp nest, don't remove yourself, they are a protected species.
@Lazer It seems Sweden, again, is different: https://t.co/Oeu07oYHti (see sektion later in article, "Anticimex tips p√• hur du getings√§krar runt ditt hus:")
IMO, feature flags are an antipattern with TBD and mean that you don't make your changes small enough.
Now moving on to code reviews, and this seems to be required reading: https://t.co/E6Gw6tCo48

Interesting discussion at #SoCraTesUK now about what "passion" in software craft means,
for us,
for employers.

Is it, when used in job ads, a codified request to work overtime?

As an industry we should normalize it more that you can deliver great value as a software developer, without being passionate.

Ask yourself, if you ask for it, what do you associate with that term?

Such a beautiful framing from Helo√° in the session:
I am not a software developer. 
I work as a software developer.
We now have shifted to the topic of #loyality. How much of it does an employer deserve?
Can't watch this with a straight face ... https://t.co/VVU8kuw3gU
#SoCraTesUK was fantastic again, big thanks to everyone who made it happen! üíØüåü

@pati_gallardo I do this to lift everyone's sprits. I. The face of challenging situation it helps to get everyone's mind off the issue for a second, and also make clear that no life is at stake. 
It gives some space to take a short break and consider all options.

@pati_gallardo I learned this as a track and field coach for small kids, and in the military as well: it's important to follow rules and regulations (e.g. for safety reasons). But, noone has the capacity to be point 100% of the time: Slack-space is important to build connections, and trust.

I attended the 24 hour liquid ensemble programming for a while and IMHO it served well to show people how ensemble programming works, and what tools and techniques exist to facilitate ensemble programming.

However having people work on a codebase they don't know, in a language they have no experience with, and people hopping on and off dilutes the perceived usefulness of this technique. I hope people try this with their own codebase again.
Thanks to @alterisian and @CuriousAgilist for setting this up!
@Lazer Have you checked the contacts that connect to the battery? Over time those can get bend and lose connection. Bending the slightly towards the battery contacts can sometimes help.
